sen.j: 谷口 藹山（たにぐち あいざん、文化 (日本)13年（1816年） - 明治32年（1899年））は、幕末から明治期の日本の画家。
sen.e: Aizan TANIGUCHI (1816 - 1899) was a Japanese painter from the end of Edo period to the Meiji period.
Aizan TANIGUCHI (1816 - 1899) was a Japanese painter who lived during a period from the end of Edo period to the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: 幕末から明治期の→who lived from the end of Edo period to the Meiji period（"who lived"の表現に変更しました。）
sen.e: Aizan TANIGUCHI (1816 - 1899) was a Japanese painter who lived during a period from the end of Edo period to the Meiji period.

sen.j: 越中国新川郡鉾ノ木村（現在の 富山県立山町）に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Hokonoki-mura Village, Niikawa-gun County, Ecchu Province (present Tateyama-cho, Toyama Prefecture).
He was born in Hokonoki Village, Niikawa County, Ecchu Province (present-day Tateyama-cho, Toyama Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。
sen.e: He was born in Hokonoki Village, Niikawa County, Ecchu Province (present-day Tateyama-cho, Toyama Prefecture).

sen.j: 名は貞二（さだじ）、字を士幹（しかん）、号は藹山、別号に鴨浙水荘（おうせつすいそう）。
sen.e: His name was Sadaji, his azana Shikan, his appellation Aizan and his another appellation Osetsu Suiso.
While he was given the names Aizan and Osetsu Suiso as his go (byname), his actual name was Sadaji TANIGUCHI and his nickname was Shikan.
sen.cmt: "his azana" "his appellation"の後に動詞が用いられていないため、文章として不完全ですので修正しました。
sen.e: While he was given the names Aizan and Osetsu Suiso as his go (byname), his actual name was Sadaji TANIGUCHI and his nickname was Shikan.

sen.j: よく「靄山」と表記されるがこれは誤り。
sen.e: His name is frequently written as 'aizan,' which is wrong.
Aizan written as '藹山' in Japanese is often written incorrectly as '靄山.'
sen.cmt: 漢字表記の違いについての記述なので、漢字表記にしました。
sen.e: Aizan written as '藹山' in Japanese is often written incorrectly as '靄山.'

sen.j: 画号の「藹山」は師の 高久靄厓の命名であり、「青は藍より出でて藍より青し」という荀子の格言から弟子が師を超える意が含まれている。
sen.e: His artist's appellation of 'Aizan' was given by Aigai TAKAKU, which indicates a proverb of Junshi (Xun Zi) meaning 'The disciple has surpassed his master.'

His pen name, 'Aizan,' was given by his master, Aigai (written as '靄厓' in Japanese) TAKAKU, and contained a meaning that a disciple would go beyond a master based on the proverb of Junshi (Xun Zi) that 'the scholar may be better than the master.'
sen.cmt: 「青は藍より出でて藍より青し」→the scholar may be better than the master [http://contest2004.thinkquest.jp/tqj2004/70237/a/aohaaiyori.htmlより]
sen.e: His pen name, 'Aizan,' was given by his master, Aigai (written as '靄厓' in Japanese) TAKAKU, and contained a meaning that a disciple would go beyond a master based on the proverb of Junshi (Xun Zi) that 'the scholar may be better than the master.'

sen.j: 靄厓の「靄」（もや）に対して「藹」（樹木が繁って盛んな様子の意）を充て、「厓」（崖・がけ）に対して「山」を合わせて「藹山」とした。
sen.e: The appellation of 'Aizan' consists of 'Ai' (wooded) versus 'Ai' (haze) and 'zan' (mountain) versus 'gai' (cliff), which was created to mean the above proverb.

Therefore, it was decided to write Aizan as '藹山' in Japanese using two Chinese characters of '藹' (referring to a wooded and abundant landscape) and '山' (referring to a mountain) instead of Chinese characters '靄' (referring to mist) and '厓' (referring to a cliff) which composed his master's pen name, 靄厓.
sen.cmt: それぞれの漢字が持つ意味を示すことにより、何故「靄山」と表記するのかを、説明しているので、それぞれの漢字を表記しました。
sen.e: Therefore, it was decided to write Aizan as '藹山' in Japanese using two Chinese characters of '藹' (referring to a wooded and abundant landscape) and '山' (referring to a mountain) instead of Chinese characters '靄' (referring to mist) and '厓' (referring to a cliff) which composed his master's pen name, 靄厓.

sen.j: 幼少より絵を好み、18歳で江戸に出るとすぐ、谷文晁に就き文齋と号した。
sen.e: While he liked painting from his childhood, he went up to Edo at the age of 18, soon began studying under Buncho TANI and took the name of Bunsai.
Aizan who had been fond of paintings from his childhood started studying under Buncho TANI soon after coming to Edo at the age of 18, and was given the name Bunsai.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。
sen.e: Aizan who had been fond of paintings from his childhood started studying under Buncho TANI soon after coming to Edo at the age of 18, and was given the name Bunsai.

sen.j: しかし納得が行かず、すぐに高久靄厓の門下となり藹山と号し、25歳まで門人として過ごす。
sen.e: However, as he felt unsatisfactory, he soon became a disciple of Aigai TAKAKU taking the name of Aizan and lead his life as a disciple until the age of 25.
However, as he felt dissatisfied, he immediately became a disciple of Aigai TAKAKU, called himself Aizan, and stayed as a disciple until the age of 25.
sen.cmt: 簡潔な表現に変更しました。
sen.e: However, as he felt dissatisfied, he immediately became a disciple of Aigai TAKAKU, called himself Aizan, and stayed as a disciple until the age of 25.

sen.j: 26歳のとき、大坂の篠崎小竹に儒学を学ぶ。
sen.e: At the age of 26, he studied Confucianism under Shochiku SHINOZAKI of Osaka.
At the age of 26, he learned Confucianism from Shochiku SHINOZAKI in Osaka.
sen.cmt: ＡにＢを学ぶ→learn B from A（簡単な表現に変更しました。）
sen.e: At the age of 26, he learned Confucianism from Shochiku SHINOZAKI in Osaka.

sen.j: その後、九州に遊学し、大分では広瀬淡窓の咸宜園で修行、長崎では清国の画家 陳逸舟に四君子などの書法を伝授される。
sen.e: Afterward, he went to kyushu to study.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: While visiting Kyushu to study, he practiced paintings at Kangien of Tanso HIROSE in Oita, and received instructions on shoho (calligraphy) of Shikunshi (four plants with high virtue) and so on from Chen Yizhou (Chin Isshu), a Chinese painter of Qing Dynasty, in Nagasaki.
sen.cmt: 文章を分割する必要がないので、下の文章と併せて、1つの文章に変更し、和文も変更しました。和文の変更箇所は、赤字にて表記しました。書法→shoho(calligraphy)（用語集に従い、小文字表記にしました。）
sen.e: While visiting Kyushu to study, he practiced paintings at Kangien of Tanso HIROSE in Oita, and received instructions on shoho (calligraphy) of Shikunshi (four plants with high virtue) and so on from Chen Yizhou (Chin Isshu), a Chinese painter of Qing Dynasty, in Nagasaki.

sen.j: 29歳にて、京都の貫名菘翁に入門。
sen.e: At the age of 29, he became a disciple of Suo NUKINA in Kyoto.
At the age of 29, he became a disciple of Suo NUKINA in Kyoto.
At the age of 29, he became a disciple of Suo NUKINA in Kyoto.

sen.j: そのまま京都の護王神社付近の家を終の住み処とした。
sen.e: He remained in Kyoto living in a house near Goo-jinja Shrine, which ended up being his last dwelling house.
He remained in Kyoto, and decided to live in a house near Goo-jinja Shrine until the end of his days.
sen.cmt: 「終の住み処とした」は「死ぬまでその家に住むことを決めた」の意味であり、簡潔な表現に変更しました。
sen.e: He remained in Kyoto, and decided to live in a house near Goo-jinja Shrine until the end of his days.

sen.j: 山水画、花鳥画を得意としたが、安政2年（1855年）、京都御所の修復時、望月玉泉らと障壁画を描いた。
sen.e: While he was good at Sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) and Kacho-ga (painting of flowers and birds), he painted on the walls or Fusuma with Gyokusen MOCHIZUKI and others at the time of repair of the Kyoto Imperial palace in 1855.
sen.cmt: 「望月玉泉」の読みは、下記サイトから引用しました。http://www.iida-museum.org/user/art/iwasaki/100-gyokusen.html
sen.e: Although he specialized in Sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) and Kacho-ga (painting of flowers and birds), Aizan engaged in wall paintings at the Kyoto Imperial Palace with Gyokusen MOCHIZUKI and others when it was repaired in 1855.
sen.cmt: ～を得意とする→specialize in ～（この場合の「得意」は、「専門とする」の意味となるので、変更しました。）（得意とした）が、→Although（"although"で始まる文章に変更しました。）
sen.e: Although he specialized in Sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) and Kacho-ga (painting of flowers and birds), Aizan engaged in wall paintings at the Kyoto Imperial Palace with Gyokusen MOCHIZUKI and others when it was repaired in 1855.

sen.j: この頃、西郷隆盛や大久保利通などの勤王の志士らとの交流を重ねている。
sen.e: Around that time, he deepened cultural exchanges with royalist political reformers including Takamori SAIGO and Toshimichi OKUBO.
Around that time, he often made personal contacts with royalists including Takamori SAIGO, Toshimichi OKUBO and so on.
sen.cmt: 勤王の志士→royalists（「勤王志士」の英訳を採用しました。）交流→make personal contacts
sen.e: Around that time, he often made personal contacts with royalists including Takamori SAIGO, Toshimichi OKUBO and so on.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）には西園寺公望が開校した私塾立命館に富岡鉄斎、山中静逸らとともに講師として招かれる。
sen.e: In 1869, he was invited with Tessai TOMIOKA, Seiitsu YAMANAKA and others to be an instructor at Ritsumei-kan private school established by Kinmochi SAIONJI.
In 1869, he was invited to Shijuku Ritsumeikan (Ritsumeikan Private Academy) established by Kinmochi SAIONJI, as an instructor along with Tessai TOMIOKA, Seiitsu YAMANAKA and others.
sen.cmt: 私塾立命館→Shijuku Ritsumeikan (Ritsumeikan Private Academy)
sen.e: In 1869, he was invited to Shijuku Ritsumeikan (Ritsumeikan Private Academy) established by Kinmochi SAIONJI, as an instructor along with Tessai TOMIOKA, Seiitsu YAMANAKA and others.

sen.j: 明治13年（1880年）64歳のとき、京都府画学校（のちの京都市立芸術大学）の南画担当教授となる。
sen.e: In 1880 at the age of 64, he became a professor of Nanga (a school of painting originating in China) in Kyoto-fu Gagakko (Kyoto Prefectural School of Painting)(later, Kyoto City University of Arts).

In 1880 when he was 64 years old, he became a professor of nanga (a school of painting originating in China) at Kyoto-fu Gagakko (Kyoto Prefectural School of Painting) (later, Kyoto City University of Arts).
sen.cmt: 南画→nanga（用語集に合わせて小文字表記に変更しました。）～学校の教授→professor at ～（"in"は使わないので、前置詞を訂正しました。）
sen.e: In 1880 when he was 64 years old, he became a professor of nanga (a school of painting originating in China) at Kyoto-fu Gagakko (Kyoto Prefectural School of Painting) (later, Kyoto City University of Arts).

sen.j: 同時期には望月玉泉（大和絵）、小山三造（洋画）、鈴木百年(鈴木派)や幸野楳嶺（四条派）が同校の教授となっている。
sen.e: In the same period of time, Gyokusen MOCHIZUKI (Yamato-e painting (a traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes)), Sanzo KOYAMA (Western paintings), Hyakunen SUZUKI (Suzuki school), Bairei KONO (Shijo-ha school) and others became professors of the same school.

sen.j: 明治29年（1896年）には田能村直入や富岡鉄斎らと日本南画協会を設立。
sen.e: In 1896, he established the Nanga Association of Japan with Chokunyu TANOMURA, Tessai TOMIOKA and others.

sen.j: 以降、京都画壇の長老として敬われた。
sen.e: Since then, he was respected as a patriarch of Kyoto art world.
Since then, he has been respected as a patriarch of Kyoto art world.
